question_text: Why might a technician prefer a loopback plug over a network cable and remote tester when diagnosing a NIC issue?
answer_options: Loopback plugs consume less power from the NIC
They work better with fiber interfaces
They test the NIC in isolation, without network dependency
They encrypt the test signal for security
correct_answer: They test the NIC in isolation, without network dependency
explanation: Loopback plugs allow direct, local verification of NIC transmit/receive circuitry without relying on remote connectivity or network infrastructure.
